content: How can I help you today?

I’ve just been feeling really overwhelmed lately. My wife and I have been struggling to help our son, and it’s putting so much strain on everything—our marriage, work, even just being able to enjoy life. She insisted I come talk to someone, but honestly, I don’t know if this will help.

It sounds like things have been especially tough for you lately, with a lot weighing on you in both your family and personal life. It can feel overwhelming when so many areas of life feel strained at the same time. What has this been like for you to carry all of this, and what made you decide to give this conversation a try today?

Honestly, it’s just been exhausting. I feel like I’m failing as a husband, a dad, and even at work because I can’t keep my head straight. The only reason I agreed to this is because my wife kept insisting—it feels like a last-ditch effort to hold everything together. I’m not sure I even believe I can turn this around.

It sounds like you're carrying a heavy load right now, and you're feeling pulled in so many directions that it's been hard to see a way forward. Agreeing to have this conversation, even when you're unsure it will help, says a lot about how much you care about your family and their well-being. What do you think is at the heart of what’s making everything feel so overwhelming right now?

I think it's feeling like no matter what I do, it's not enough. My son is still struggling, my wife and I are always tense or arguing, and I’m losing the little connection I had with my daughter. I feel like I’m failing everyone, and it’s just piling up. It’s hard to even know where to start.

It sounds like you’re carrying a deep sense of responsibility, and it’s painful to feel like your efforts aren’t making things better. The weight of trying to support everyone while feeling that connection is fraying must be incredibly draining. It’s understandable that not knowing where to start can make it all feel even harder. What’s been keeping you going through all of this?

I guess what keeps me going is wanting my family to be okay. I don’t want my marriage to fall apart, and I want to help my son—he deserves that. I just feel like I’m running out of fuel, and I don’t know how to fix any of this.

Your commitment to your family really shines through—it’s clear how deeply you care about them and want to be there for them. It’s no wonder you’re feeling so drained, carrying all of this while trying to hold everything together. While you’ve been giving so much of yourself, it makes sense that you're unsure where to look for the next step. What do you think would bring even a small sense of relief or progress in this situation?

I don’t really know, to be honest. Maybe if I could figure out how to help my son, everything else might fall into place a little more. But it feels like we’ve tried so much already and nothing works, so I’m not sure how hopeful I am about that.

Focusing on helping your son feels really important to you—it sounds like you believe that making progress there might ripple out and help ease some of the strain in other areas. At the same time, after trying so much without seeing results, it makes sense that you're feeling discouraged about what’s possible. What’s been the most challenging part of trying to help him so far?

I think the hardest part is that we don’t understand what’s really going on with him. He just lashes out or shuts down, and no matter what we do—whether it’s being patient or setting boundaries—it feels like we're stuck in the same cycle. It’s heartbreaking because we just want to help him, but we don’t even know where to start.

It sounds incredibly hard to see your son struggling and feel unsure about how to help. You’re trying so many different approaches, and yet being stuck in that same cycle has left you feeling both heartbroken and uncertain. Your desire to understand and support him is clear, and it's coming from such a caring place. What do you think might help you feel more equipped to approach this situation with him?

I'm not sure, honestly. Maybe if we had a better idea of what’s causing his behavior or if there were resources or people who could guide us. I think we’re just tired of feeling like we’re guessing all the time and not getting anywhere.

It makes sense that feeling like you’re guessing all the time would leave you feeling worn out and stuck. It sounds like you’re open to the idea of getting some guidance or exploring resources to better understand what’s going on with your son. What do you think would be the first step toward finding that kind of support?

Maybe reaching out to someone like a child therapist or a professional who has experience with kids going through challenges like his? It’s still hard for me to fully trust that even they could help, but I don’t think we can keep doing this alone.

Reaching out to a child therapist or professional would be a big step forward, especially since you’re recognizing that it’s hard to keep carrying this alone. Even though there’s some hesitation and uncertainty about how much it might help, it sounds like you’re beginning to see the value in having someone with experience guide your family. How would it feel to take that step and look into connecting with support for your son?

It feels like a mix of relief and anxiety, honestly. Relief because maybe someone could finally help us figure out what’s happening, but anxiety because it’s hard to admit we can’t fix this on our own. It’s a big step, and I guess I’m just scared of what we might hear or if it won’t work.

It’s completely natural to feel that mix of relief and anxiety. Taking this step means opening up to the possibility of help, which can feel like a weight lifted, but also stepping into the unknown can bring fear of what you might discover or if things might not change. Admitting that you can’t fix this alone takes courage, and it shows how much you care about doing what’s best for your family. What do you think could help you feel a little stronger or more supported as you take this next step?

Maybe if my wife and I approached it as a team, it wouldn’t feel so overwhelming. Knowing she’s already seeing a counselor makes me think she might have some insights or ideas to help us move forward together. I guess just not feeling like I have to shoulder all of this alone might make the process easier to face.

Approaching this as a team with your wife sounds like it could make a big difference for both of you. It’s a way to share the weight and offer each other support as you take on this challenge together. It sounds like her seeing a counselor already might bring some helpful perspectives for moving forward as a family. How would it feel for you to start that conversation with her about working together in this way?
